title: Chinese Government provides RMB 100 million interest-free loan for Bangabandhu International Convention Centre Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#33940)
description: On April 2, 2000, the Government of Bangladesh and the Chinese Government signed an RMB 100 million interest-free loan agreement for the China-Bangladesh Friendship Conference Center Construction Project. The total cost of the project was 2 billion taka. The loan carried the following borrowing terms: a 0% interest rate, a 10-year grace period, and a 15-year maturity. title: Chinese Government provides RMB 200 million interest-free loan for Di-Ammonium Phosphate Fertilizer Plant Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#33929 and #38969)
description: In 2000, the Chinese Government offered $53.29 million of debt financing to the Government of Bangladesh for the Di-Ammonium Phosphate Fertilizer Plant Construction Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) agreed to issue an RMB 200 million loan for the project. The loan agreement between MOFCOM and the Government of Bangladesh (captured via Project ID#39369) was finalized on September 13, 2000 and it carried the following borrowing terms: a 15-year maturity, a 10-year grace period, and a 0% interest rate. China Eximbank and the Government of Bangladesh also signed an RMB 239,667,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the project on September 7, 2005 (captured via Project ID#33929).   The GCL carried the following borrowing terms: a 16-year maturity, a 4-year grace period, a 2% interest rate, and a 0.2% commitment fee (service charge). The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the GCL and the interest-free loan to partially finance a $59.21 million commercial contract between China National Complete Plant Import and Export Corporation Limited (COMPLANT) and Bangladesh Chemical Industries Corporation (BCIC). According to the Government of Bangladesh’s Economic Relations Division (ERD), the interest-free loan from MOFCOM had achieved a disbursement rate of 100% (RMB 200,000,000 out of RMB 200,000,000) as of June 30, 2014 and the borrower had repaid RMB 187,500,000 to MOFCOM as of June 30, 2014. According to the Government of Bangladesh’s ERD, the GCL had achieved a disbursement rate of 100% (RMB 239,667,000 out of RMB 239,667,000) as of June 30, 2014 and the borrower had repaid China Eximbank RMB 132,353,000 as of June 30, 2014 and RMB 239,667,000 as of June 30, 2019.   The purpose of the project was to build an 800-ton-per-day di-ammonia phosphate fertilizer plant in the Anowara Upazilla (SubDistrict) of Chittagong Division. COMPLANT was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction of the di-ammonium phosphate fertilizer plant — known as Di-Ammonium Phosphate Fertiliser Company Ltd (DAPFCL) — was originally expected to begin at the end of 2000 and projected to commence operations within 30 months (July 1, 2003). However, the project did not commence until April 2004 and it was not completed until June 2006. Then, in August 2016, an ammonia tank at the plant exploded, causing at least 50 people to fall sick from inhaling toxic gas. The emission of toxic ammonia at the fertilizer factory was brought under control on August 23, 2016, some 11 hours after one of two smaller 500-tonne capacity ammonia storage tanks exploded. Fifty people, including women, were admitted to the Chittagong Medical College Hospital (CMCH). BCIC, which now runs the factory, formed a 10-member committee to investigate the incident.
staff_comments: 1. The Government of Bangladesh loan identification number for the MOFCOM interest-free loan is L1120000913a. The Government of Bangladesh loan identification number for the China Eximbank GCL is L1120050907a 2. The project is also known as the MTDP DI-AMMONIUM PHOSPHATE (DAP) Project and the 800 Metric Tons of 800 MT DI-AMMONIUM PHOSPHATE (DAP) Project. 3. Some sources suggest that COMPLANT also agreed to provide a $29.11 million supplier’s credit, which in turn was funded with the proceeds from an export seller’s credit that it received. This issue warrants further investigation.

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 73.5 million governmental concessional loan for Textile Factory Project (Linked to Project ID#73357, #73365, and #73366)
description: On June 18, 1998, the Chinese Government and the Government of Benin signed an RMB 150 million preferential loan framework agreement for the Textile Factory Project. Under the terms of this agreement, a Chinese state-owned company, China Textile Industry Foreign Economic and Technical Cooperation Company (CTEXIC), and a Beninese state-owned company, Société des Industries Textiles du Bénin (SITEX), agreed to create a joint venture called Compagnie Béninoise de Textile (CBT).  Rather than issuing a single RMB 150 million loan to CBT, the Export-Import Bank of China issued one loan to the Government of Benin (on behalf of SITEX) and another loan to CTEXIC. The face values of these loans, which sum to RMB 150 million, were issued in proportion to the SITEX ownership stake (49%) and CTEXIC ownership stake (51%) in CBT.  On January 13, 2000, China Eximbank and La Caisse Autonome d'Amortissement du Bénin (a public sector institution supervised by Benin’s Ministry of the Economy and Finance) signed an RMB 73.5 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [China Eximbank GCL NO. (2000) 1 (57)] for the Textile Factory Project. This loan carried the following borrowing terms: a 15-year maturity, a 5-year grace period, an interest rate of 3%, a default (penalty) interest rate, a 0.3% commitment fee, and a 0.25% management fee. The borrower agreed to deposit project-related revenues in a special account to facilitate repayment. Project ID#18 captures the loan that was issued to La Caisse Autonome d'Amortissement du Bénin.  In March 2000, China Eximbank and CTEXIC signed an RMB 76.5 million loan agreement for the Textile Factory Project. The borrowing terms of this loan are unknown. Project ID#73357 captures the loan that was issued to CTEXIC.  The company was formally registered and established in Cotonou in February 2000. This project supported the construction, operation and management of a textile factory in the city of Lokassa called Compagnie Béninoise de Textile (CBT). The main factory building was designed with 24,000 cotton spindles and 768 weaving looms. It was built to achieve a production capacity of 13.7 million meters of unbleached cotton fabric and 923 tons of pure cotton yarn. The factory was put into production on October 31, 2002.  CBT subsequently encountered financial problems and China Eximbank had to reschedule its loans with La Caisse Autonome d'Amortissement du Bénin and CTEXIC. China Eximbank reportedly rescheduled its loan to La Caisse Autonome d'Amortissement du Bénin in 2004 and its loan to CTEXIC on August 23, 2011 The terms of the 2004 rescheduling are unknown; however, it is known that the 2011 rescheduling resulted in a reduction of the loan’s interest rate to 1%. The 2004 loan restructuring is captured via Project ID#73365, and the 2011 restructuring is captured via Project ID#73366.  As of 2018, SITEX had gone bankrupt and was looking to restructure, but the CBT factory was in production with 1200 employees (5 of whom were Chinese and 1,995 of whom were Beninese).

Neither the RMB 73.5 million loan that China Eximbank issued to La Caisse Autonome d'Amortissement du Bénin nor the RMB 76.5 million loan that China Eximbank issued to CTEXIC are included in the database of Chinese loan commitments that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020.3. This loan carried the following borrowing terms: a 12 year maturity, a 4 year grace period, and a 4% interest rate. The face value of the loan was subsequently revised to RMB 19,490,521. The Government of Botswana used the proceeds from the loan to on-lend to the Botswana Housing Corporation (BHC) at a significantly higher interest rate (approximately 8.5%). The BHC, in turn, used the proceeds from its subsidiary loan agreement with the Government of Botswana to construct 86 housing units in the town of Kasane. Complant Botswana (Pty) Ltd., a subsidiary of China National Overseas Engineering Corporation, was the contractor responsible for implementation. This project was completed, but its precise date of completion is unknown.
staff_comments: 1. Some sources indicate that this loan was secured in late 1999 and others indicate that it was secured in 2000. 2. There is also disagreement across sources with respect to the final maturity date of the loan. SAIS-CARI records a maturity length of 16 years. Botswana’s Ministry of Finance and Economic Development records a maturity = of 12 years. AidData relies on the maturity that is recorded by Botswana’s Ministry of Finance and Economic Development.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant for education and social sector projects
description: On December 22, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of Bulgaria signed an exchange of letters, which committed RMB 5 million of grant funding ($600,000) for education and social sector projects in Bulgaria.   The agreement was signed by Nadezhda Mihailova (Nadezhda Mikhaylova), the Foreign Minister of Bulgaria, and Tang Jiaxuan, and the Chinese Foreign Minister. It is unclear whether or how this financial commitment was implemented.
